description: the configuration for grading criteria which be used for LLMentor

criteria.name: Language/Quality
criteria.description: Assessment of language quality and structural coherence of the text

rubrics.name: Language quality
rubrics.description: Evaluation of linguistic accuracy and sentence clarity

scoring.description: many linguistic errors (over 10 errors) (e.g. wrong tense, wrong personal pronouns)
few linguistic errors (0-10 errors), clear and comprehensible sentences
no linguistic errors (0 errors), clear and comprehensible sentences with consistent terminology

rubrics.name: Common Thread
rubrics.description: Assessment of structural continuity and coherence throughout the text

scoring.description: No recognizable common thread, the structure is unclear and jumpy
Partly recognizable, but the structure is not continuous
Text has a continuous structure that is easy to follow, common thread is clear and recognizable from beginning to end

criteria.name: Metadata
criteria.description: Evaluation of title appropriateness and creativity

rubrics.name: Preliminary title
rubrics.description: Assessment of how well the title matches and represents the topic

scoring.description: Title does not match the topic
Title fits the topic; similar title to the one in the topic suggestions
Title fits the topic; creative title changed in a novel way and/or fits into the story of the synopsis

rubrics.name: Metadata available
rubrics.description: Assessment of proper student identification information

scoring.description: Name, date and matriculation number are not entered correctly/changed
Name, date, matriculation number are correct and updated

criteria.name: Form/Structure
criteria.description: Evaluation of document formatting and structural requirements

rubrics.name: Template used
rubrics.description: LaTeX template used

scoring.description: Latex template is not used
Latex template is used

rubrics.name: Number of pages
rubrics.description: Page limitation for more focused writing

scoring.description: > three pages (motivation + approach only)
<= three sides (motivation + approach only)

criteria.name: Motivation
criteria.description: Assessment of problem identification, context establishment, and research question formulation

rubrics.name: Hook existing
rubrics.description: Evaluation of the presence and suitability of an engaging opening

scoring.description: Hook not available
Hook present and suitable for the topic

rubrics.name: Anker
rubrics.description: Assessment of problem statement detail and comprehensiveness

scoring.description: The problem is not mentioned at all.
The problem is stated in general terms without specific details. It is recognizable which problem is being addressed, but important information is omitted.
The problem is described in detail. All relevant aspects of the problem are mentioned and clarify its scope and possible effects.

rubrics.name: Domain
rubrics.description: Evaluation of context and domain specification for the problem

scoring.description: The domain or context in which the problem occurs is not mentioned.
The domain or the relevant expert area of the problem is mentioned. It is clear in which environment the problem exists.

rubrics.name: Problem relevance
rubrics.description: Assessment of how well the importance and impact of the problem is communicated

scoring.description: The relevance or importance of the problem is not addressed. It remains unclear why this problem is relevant or worth discussing.

The importance and relevance of the problem is described. It is made clear why the problem is important and what impact or consequences it could have (e.g. for specific individuals, organisations or society as a whole).

rubrics.name: Problem handling
rubrics.description: Evaluation of current approaches or criticisms regarding the problem

scoring.description: current handling of the problem or current criticism is not given
current handling of the problem or current criticism is given

rubrics.name: Teaser (RQ)
rubrics.description: Assessment of research question clarity and alignment with problem description

scoring.description: There is no research question available

A research question exists, but it has weaknesses, e.g. due to unclear terminology or vague formulation. It is difficult to recognise what is to be investigated and how the question fits the problem description.
The research question is formulated clearly and precisely. It clearly conveys what is to be investigated, and fits thematically with the problem description.

rubrics.name: RQ Limitation
rubrics.description: Evaluation of research question scope and feasibility for Bachelor's thesis context

scoring.description: The research question is either too general or too broad, so that it does not seem realistic to answer it within the scope of a Bachelor's thesis, to answer it in the context of a Bachelor's thesis.

The research question is precise and clearly defined so that it can realistically be addressed in the context of a Bachelor's thesis. The question is formulated in concrete terms and describes specifically which aspects are to be investigated without deviating from the topic.

criteria.name: Approach
criteria.description: Assessment of state of the art analysis, theoretical framework, and methodology

rubrics.name: SOTA
rubrics.description: Evaluation of state of the art presence and proper citation

scoring.description: SOTA not available
SOTA present and correctly cited

rubrics.name: SOTA Relevance
rubrics.description: Assessment of how well the relevance of state of the art is demonstrated

scoring.description: The relevance of SOTA is not present or unclear.
The relevance of SOTA is mentioned, but is only partially comprehensible or weakly presented.
It is clearly shown how SOTA is relevant to the topic of the exposé and why it is relevant to the research.

rubrics.name: SOTA Weaknesses
rubrics.description: Evaluation of identification and explanation of state of the art limitations

scoring.description: SOTA's weak points are not mentioned
SOTA's weaknesses are mentioned, but only superficially or unclearly described
SOTA's weaknesses are clearly identified and precisely explained; it is clear which weaknesses are relevant for own research

rubrics.name: SOTA Delimitation
rubrics.description: Assessment of differentiation between own work and existing research

scoring.description: No differentiation of own performance from the current state of research
The own achievement is differentiated from SOTA; it is explicitly emphasized, what is new or unique about your own research

rubrics.name: SOTA Combination
rubrics.description: Evaluation of meaningful combination and consolidation of existing material

scoring.description: No meaningful combination of existing material (even if reference is made to existing material, but its combination or consolidation is unconvincing or unclear)
Existing material is clearly and meaningfully combined; the added value of the combination is clear.

rubrics.name: Theoretical Framework
rubrics.description: Assessment of theoretical framework structure and clarity

scoring.description: The theoretical framework does not exist or is completely misleading
The theoretical framework is present, but unclear, poorly structured or difficult to understand
The theoretical framework is clearly and logically structured. The theoretical approaches are presented in a understandable and comprehensible

rubrics.name: Relevance of theoretical framework
rubrics.description: Evaluation of theoretical framework connection to research topic

scoring.description: The theoretical framework shows no connection to the research topic, or the theory is irrelevant
The theoretical framework clearly demonstrates how the selected theories directly relate to the research topic and support the research question

rubrics.name: Methodology Availability
rubrics.description: Assessment of methodology presence and suitability for research questions

scoring.description: Methodology not available
Methodology available and suitable for answering the RQ(s)

rubrics.name: Methodology Completeness
rubrics.description: Evaluation of methodology coverage of all research questions

scoring.description: Methodology is available, but not all RQ(s) are addressed
Methodology is available and addresses all points of the research questions

rubrics.name: Methodology Relevance
rubrics.description: Assessment of methodology relevance and contribution to research project

scoring.description: The relevance of the methodology for the research project is not clear or is unclear
It is clearly and precisely demonstrated why the chosen methodology is relevant to the research project and how it contributes to the research questions

rubrics.name: Methodology Target group
rubrics.description: Evaluation of target group specification and relevance

scoring.description: The target group is not specified or there is no precise differentiation
The target group is clearly and precisely defined and it is clear why it is relevant to the methodology

rubrics.name: Methodology Existing Material
rubrics.description: Assessment of appropriate reference to existing material in methodology

scoring.description: No reference is made to the existing material or the material is inappropriate
The existing material is appropriately and accurately related to the topic; it is clear that this material is relevant to the methodology

rubrics.name: Methodology Difficulties
rubrics.description: Evaluation of identification and solutions for potential implementation challenges

scoring.description: Potential difficulties in the practical implementation of the methods are not addressed. Potential challenges that could hinder the research process are overlooked.

Potential difficulties in the practical implementation of the methods are described clearly and precisely. Concrete solutions or strategies to overcome these difficulties are also presented, in order to organize the research process as efficiently and target-oriented as possible.

rubrics.name: Methodology Possibilities/restrictions
rubrics.description: Assessment of methodology strengths, limitations, and critical reflection

scoring.description: The possibilities or limitations of the methods used are not addressed, or they are only mentioned superficially, without concrete details. It remains unclear how these methods contribute to answering the research question and which limitations could possibly influence the validity of the results.

The possibilities and limitations of the methods are described clearly and precisely. It is clear what strengths the methods bring to the study and what weaknesses or limitations could possibly influence the results. limitations could possibly influence the results. The choice of methods is critically reflected upon and related to the research project.

rubrics.name: Methodology Details
rubrics.description: Evaluation of comprehensive methodology explanation and implementation details

scoring.description: No additional explanations are given on the methodology or implementation
The methodology is explained comprehensively and precisely with additional explanations (e.g. details on implementation),  so that the procedure is clearly comprehensible

criteria.name: Schedule
criteria.description: Assessment of project timeline structure, completeness, and realism

rubrics.name: Schedule Availability
rubrics.description: Evaluation of tabular schedule presence and chronological organization

scoring.description: Tabular schedule not available
Tabular schedule in chronological order available

rubrics.name: Schedule Completeness
rubrics.description: Assessment of schedule coverage and logical division into work blocks

scoring.description: Tabular schedule contains gaps
Tabular schedule available from start to finish and reasonably divided into blocks

rubrics.name: Schedule Block Description
rubrics.description: Evaluation of detailed descriptions for individual schedule blocks

scoring.description: not available or only headlines available
individual blocks described (not only headlines)

rubrics.name: Schedule Realistic Relevance
rubrics.description: Assessment of timeline realism and alignment with Bachelor's thesis scope

scoring.description: The time distribution is obviously unrealistic and important work steps are missing. The research questions are not or only insufficiently addressed

The timeline contains the most important steps, but some of the timelines are unrealistic or unclear. It is partially unclear how the steps contribute to answering the research questions. The timeline does not appear to be fully aligned with the Bachelor's thesis context.

The timeline is clearly structured, realistic and aligned with the scope of the Bachelor's thesis. All important work steps are included and organised in a sensible time frame. Each step contributes to answering the research questions, and the entire plan fits coherently into the exposé and the context of the thesis.

criteria.name: Bibliography
criteria.description: Assessment of bibliography consistency and literature relevance

rubrics.name: Bibliography Consistency
rubrics.description: Evaluation of citation style consistency and completeness of bibliographic information

scoring.description: Bibliography with different citation styles
Bibliography is standardized ( consistent citation style) and essentially all information on the literature is available

rubrics.name: Key literature
rubrics.description: Assessment of literature relevance and quality for the research topic

scoring.description: Literature does not fit the topic
Literature fits the topic
Literature fits the topic and most of it is highly relevant
